main.name: Francisco J. Mejias
main.bio: I never feel like I know enough. 7 years ago when I started working in QA I decided to also get a Masters in Internet Technology with a concentration in e-commerce. I wanted to know as much as possible about e-commerce technologies in order to become the best at what had become my career path. After I finished the degree, I was working in a project that involved building an Android and iOS app from the ground up. After getting tired of manual testing (luckily at the same time Swift was born), I started learning Swift on my own and created an automation framework to test this robust iOS app. This also allowed me to then do some work with Espresso on the Android app and freed me enough to start learning web automation. So after I became good enough at Java I joined the web-automation team and I’ve been automating test cases for over 2 years now. I still did not think I knew enough, so I completed a scholarship challenge where over 10,000 people competed to get a scholarship for a free nanodegree sponsored by Google and Udacity, and I got it. Now I have experience in iOS, Android, and web automation, and also a nanodegree to prove I know enough about frontend development to tackle JavaScript related projects. However, did I mention I never think I know enough? I’m currently reading about brain plasticity and statistics, because the future of automated testing is the automation of it, and I believe neural networks are here to help. The cool thing about being wrong regarding this prediction, is that at least I’ll learn about neural networks… and that’s already pretty cool to me! When I’m not working, you can find me playing soccer, training for a marathon, or walking my dog.

resume.skillmessage: Here is a list of the tools I use with enough propficiency to get things done on my own

work.title: QA Automation Engineer
work.description: Android, iOS, and Web Automation GUI testing for Booker Software products using Selenium with Java for web, Espresso for Android, and XCTest framework with Swift for iOS. Other duties include training newly hired QA employees on how to use these frameworks, manual API testing, taking and saving database snapshots and creating backups of our automation database.

work.title: From Tech-Support to Senior QA Analyst
work.description: I started in Tech Support and worked my way to the chain. During this time period my main duties included troubleshooting production issues, writing/executing GUI/API tests on different web/mobile projects, business-requirement analysis, and a brief experience combining QA duties for the mobile team with scrum master duties.

education.description: I received a scholarship from Udacity and Google after competing on a 3 month challenge with about 10,000 other contestants. The nanodegree covered from web foundations, to writing web applications focused mainly on React.

education.degree: Master of Science in Information Technology
education.description: Program included programming in PHP and JavaScript, Cyber Defense and Threats, Cryptology, Biometrics, Security Design Principles, Web Security, Network and Device, Forensics, Cybersecurity Policy (legal, ethics and compliance), Cloud Computing, and Data Mining

testimonials.text: Here you should write some nice things that someone has said about you. No lies though, employers can tell when you are lying.

That Tim Baker must be one of the most brilliant developers I've ever met! It is amazing that nobody has hired him yet. Hey you, you should hire this guy, he may be fresh out of University and have zero on the job experience but I am confident that he will be one of your best developers in no time!
